I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up  to  $200,000,000  equivalent  in  yuan  to  Shenzhen  Water  (Group)  Co.,  Ltd.  (SZWG)  and 
Shenzhen  Water  and  Environment  Investment  Group  Co.,  Ltd.  (SZWEIC)  for  the  Climate-
Resilient and Smart Urban Water Infrastructure Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2. 
The  proposed  project  will  support  SZWG’s  investment  in  multiple  water  supply  and 
wastewater treatment facilities with smart water technologies and climate- and disaster-resilient 
urban water infrastructure in Shenzhen and third- and fourth-tier cities in the PRC.1 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Project Identification and Description 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Project identification. The PRC is one of the world’s most water-stressed countries. Per 
capita water resources are about one-quarter of the global average,2 and 25% of its water bodies 
do not meet minimum drinking water quality standards.3 By 2030, the country will need up to 20% 
more in total water supply than it did in 2014, with a rapid increase in urban water demand.4 Water 
scarcity is exacerbated by climate change and surface water and groundwater pollution. Climatic 
changes can alter the seasonality of rainfall and intensify extreme precipitation events, straining 
drainage  and  sewerage  infrastructure  and  heightening  the  risks  of  urban  flooding.5 Enhancing 
resilience to extreme weather events associated with climate change is an emerging priority for 
cities in the PRC. 
 
4. 
In response, the Government of the PRC launched a national “sponge city” program in 
2015.  The  country’s  Thirteenth  Five-Year  Plan  (2016–2020)  for  the  Development  of  Strategic 
Emerging Industries emphasized greater use of smart water systems.6 A “sponge city” is a city 
with  a  water  infrastructure  system  that  is  capable  of  absorbing,  harvesting,  storing,  filtering, 
purifying, and slowly releasing or reusing urban runoff—in effect, acting like a sponge. A sponge 
city is designed to soak up heavy rainfall and flooding and, when needed, release stored water to 
make  it  available  for  beneficial  use.  In  these  ways,  a  sponge  city  helps  to  ensure  safe  urban 
drainage,  avoid  flooding,  reuse  rainwater,  and  protect  the  environment.  Smart  water  solutions 
utilize technological innovation to improve water quality and supply, reduce leakages, enhance 
wastewater treatment and reuse, support monitoring and evaluation, improve customer services, 
and reduce energy consumption. 
 
5. 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has long supported capacity development in areas 
of  water  supply,  wastewater  management,  integrated  water  resource  management,  flood  risk 
management,  and  enabling  the  environment  for  private  sector  participation.  Recent  examples 
include ADB assistance for preparing (i) an outline strategy to promote smart water approaches 
in a comprehensive integrated urban water system for Tianjin Municipality, (ii) a nationwide long-

6. 
Project  design.  The  loan  will  finance  multiple  urban  water  subprojects  that  support 
sponge  city  development  to  enhance  climate  resilience,  or  apply  smart  water  technology  to 
improve  efficiency  in  the  water  value  chain  from  the  supply  end  to  wastewater  treatment.  The 
project  is  designed  to  be  cost-effective  in  financing  multiple  subprojects.  Subprojects  will  be 
identified  during  the  project  implementation  period  between  2020  and  2023.  ADB  will  extend 
financing on a subproject-by-subproject basis. 
 
7. 
Eligibility  criteria.  The  majority  (60%)  of  the  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  in  third-  and 
fourth-tier  cities,  while the  rest  will  be  used  in  Shenzhen.  All  subprojects should meet  climate-
resilient  and  smart  water  technique  and  technology  requirements  and  pre-agreed  eligibility 
criteria. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
8. 
The sponsor and borrowers. SZWG is the project’s sponsor and guarantor, and SZWG 
and SZWEIC are the co-borrowers. Established in 2001, SZWG is a water utility that provides 
comprehensive water solutions and services that include urban water system management and 
wastewater  treatment  and  network  maintenance.  The  Shenzhen  Municipal  Government  is  the 
majority  owner  of  SZWG  (55%),  with  the  remaining  shares  held  indirectly  by  Veolia 
Environnement S.A. (25%)7 and Beijing Capital Co., Ltd. (20%).8 SZWEIC is a SZWG investment 
platform established in 2005 to develop, invest, and implement subprojects outside of Shenzhen. 
SZWEIC is owned by SZWG (70%) and the Shenzhen Municipal Government’s investment arm, 
Shenzhen Capital Co., Ltd. (30%). 
 
9. 
SZWG  plans  to  upgrade  the  technologies  of  water  supply  and  wastewater  treatment 
facilities to reduce nonrevenue water, optimize energy efficiency, and enhance service quality. It 
will also strengthen long-term monitoring and evaluation of urban water systems. The resulting 
improved  operational  efficiency  and  reduced  water  losses  will  lower  energy  consumption  and 
carbon emissions. 
 
10. 
SZWG’s sponge city development will be guided by modeling of surface water, weather 
patterns, drainage systems, and groundwater. It will involve low-impact development techniques 
such  as  the  use  of  wetlands,  permeable  pavements,  rainwater  gardens,  green  roofs,  storage 
facilities, wastewater reuse, and managed aquifer recharge. Sponge city development can also 
incorporate  advanced  early  warning  systems  for  floods,  weather  events,  and  pollution.  The 
sponge city is expected to contribute to climate and disaster resilience, mainly by reducing the 
severity  of  the  urban  flooding  caused  by  excessive  rainfall  and  droughts  through  storing  and 
releasing runoff in a more ecologically functional way.

11. 
SZWG aims to disseminate and bring its operational know-how from Shenzhen to smaller 
cities in the country. As of 2019, SZWG was managing 88 water supply plants with an aggregate 
daily design capacity of 9.8 million cubic meters and 41 wastewater treatment plants with total 
capacity of 4.0 million cubic meters. These plants served more than 30 million people across 22 
cities in seven provinces. SZWG is the first PRC water company to produce and distribute high-
quality  potable  water  to  households  using  a  water  safety  plan  for  streamlined  water  quality 
management through automation. In addition, SZWG has invested in research and development 
in collaboration with PRC universities and owned 52 patents and 62 utility models as of 2019.  
 
12. 
SZWG  has  completed two  sponge  city  projects and  is  keen  to  learn from  industry  best 
practices. Although SZWG has made significant progress on smart water solutions, most of them 
have  focused  on  e-payment  and  digitalized  monitoring.  SZWG  has  taken  initial  steps  to  apply 
smart water technology for climate change mitigation to reduce energy consumption. SZWG is 
also committed to improving its approaches to social and environmental management and gender 
inclusiveness, and has participated in knowledge-sharing events organized by ADB.

Pandemic  impacts.  The  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  highlights  the

and well-being. The pandemic has not had a material impact on SZWG’s project costs or capacity. 
Using digital solutions such as automation and remote monitoring, SZWG provided water supply

project processing. However, ADB’s support for crucial infrastructure through a nonsovereign loan 
is  expected  to  help  local  governments  ensure  climate  consciousness  in  economic  recovery 
efforts, and the subprojects will provide local jobs.

 Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

C. 
 
18. 
Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. By supporting greater gender 
inclusiveness  at  SZWG,  the  project  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  operational  priority  2 
(accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality).  The  project  will  include  a  gender  action  plan.  It  is 
aligned with operational priority 3 (tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, 
and enhancing environmental sustainability) by supporting the establishment of sponge cities to 
address flood risks and improving energy efficiency through the use of smart water technologies. 
By supporting water quality improvements, reducing pollution, and enhancing water  efficiency 
in PRC cities, the project is also aligned with operational priority 4 (livable cities). The project 
supports the strategic priorities of ADB’s water operational plan 2011–2020 and the objectives 
laid  out  in  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC,  2016–2020  to  manage  climate 
change and the environment and to develop green cities.11 
 
19. 
Lessons from previous operations. The ADB-supported Jiangxi–Pingxiang Integrated 
Rural–Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Project  showed  that  rigorous  demand  analyses  and 
effective policy dialogue on cost recovery benefited urban water planning and ensured investment 
sustainability. 12  ADB’s  Jilin  Yanji  Low-Carbon  Climate-Resilient  Healthy  City  Project 
demonstrated that sponge city infrastructure yielded multiple benefits, including effective defense 
against flooding; better water absorption filtering and purifying; increased biodiversity; and a more 
conducive  environment  for  recreation,  walking,  and  cycling.13 In  light  of  progress  achieved  on 
sustainable  green  growth,  ADB  should  support  the  transformation  of  traditional  urban  water 
utilities into comprehensive water environmental management providers and mobilize investment 
from the private sector to support sustainable development.

The Assistance

$200 million in yuan from its ordinary capital resources. The loan has a maturity of up to 10 years

During the life of the loan, SZWG, SZWEIC, and their subproject companies are bound by

27. 
 

ADB’s assistance provides the following additionality: 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

(i) 

(ii) 

Financial  additionality.  ADB’s  assistance  is  designed  to  improve  efficiency  by 
bundling subprojects that are too small or costly to be financed on a stand-alone 
basis. Without ADB support, SZWG would have to raise financing for each separate 
subproject through the local branches of commercial banks where the subproject is 
located. ADB adds value by linking the cluster of projects with the wider financing 
community,  including  international  financial  institutions.  ADB’s  facility  will  have  a 
catalytic  role  in  mobilizing  private  sector  resources  through  various  cofinancing 
arrangements during project implementation. 
Nonfinancial additionality. ADB’s engagement will promote gender inclusiveness

Environmental and social audit findings and recommendations. An external expert 
30. 
undertook due diligence in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements for 
general corporate finance. Due diligence included a corporate audit of SZWG’s ESMS and four 
site  audits  at  water,  wastewater  treatment,  and  sponge  city  facilities.  The  corporate  audit 
determined that SZWG was in compliance with applicable laws and regulations of the jurisdictions 
in which it operates. However, in terms of the objectives, principles, and requirements of ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement, some gaps were identified. The company’s environmental and social 
systems, processes, and practices were assessed as commensurate with the risks and impacts 
associated with its business and operations. The aspects reviewed during due diligence include 
odor  and  noise  nuisance,  waste  management,  hazardous  substance  management,  sludge 
disposal, and occupational health and safety. SZWG did not have a land procurement procedure 
in place to identify and manage unresolved or potential future displacement impacts. This was 
due largely to the fact that municipal governments carry out land procurement in the PRC and 
award land-use rights under concession agreements. As SZWG has not had and does not expect 
to have adverse or beneficial impacts on ethnic minority groups, its consideration of such groups 
in subproject planning was based on national law. 
 
31. 
 
32. 
SZWG has agreed to all audit findings and recommendations, which were reflected in the 
project’s  corrective  action  plan.  As  an  initial  action,  SZWG,  assisted  by  ADB,  will  develop  an 
ESMS that satisfies ADB requirements. ADB assistance has included drafting of specific ESMS 
procedures, and ADB will also support staff training. The ESMS will include an environmental and 
social  compliance  audit  procedure  for  SZWG  to  confirm  that  subprojects  utilizing  ADB  loan 
proceeds  comply  with  ADB  requirements.  SZWG  will  submit  each  subproject  audit  to  ADB  for 
approval before disbursement. Compliance audits will be disclosed on the ADB website. SZWG 
will  submit  annual  reports  on  each  ADB-financed  subproject  to  ADB  to  confirm  ongoing 
compliance with ADB requirements set out in the ESMS. 
 
33. 
Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998), SZWG has incorporated measures to promote gender equality and/or the empowerment 
of women in its business activities.  ADB conducted a gender analysis of SZWG during project 
preparation. The gender action plan calls for (i) increasing the number of women in mid-level or 
high-level management; (ii) developing SZWG’s human resource policy to include measures that 
increase  the  proportion  of  women  staff  recruited,  retained,  and  promoted;  (iii)  increasing  the 
proportion of female employees participating in professional training that can help advance their 
careers;  and  (iv)  developing  a  knowledge  product  on  how  sponge  city  and  smart  water 
technologies  can  help  women  become  more  resilient  to  the  effects  of  climate  change  and 
disasters. SZWG will submit periodic reports on the implementation of gender measures to ADB.
